caption:
This photograph captures a vibrant urban street scene, presumably taken in the mid-20th century based on the style of the vehicles and architecture. The image shows a busy roadway lined with a variety of vehicles, including buses and cars. In the foreground, an older model bus with a distinctive white body and a striped design is visible; it is marked with the number "120." It is accompanied by a classic American car from the 1960s or 1970s, identifiable by its sleek, long body and large front grille.

Also evident in the scene is a second bus with the number "4172," sporting a similar design but with a different color stripe. There are several other vehicles, including another bus and a vintage van, providing a glimpse into the diverse traffic of the era.

The setting is an urban street with tall buildings. One of the buildings has a clear sign reading "FIDELITY," suggesting itâ€™s possibly a bank or financial institution. There are mature trees along the sidewalk, and multiple pedestrians are visible. A man in a suit is just stepping off the curb, and a few other pedestrians appear to be waiting or walking near the buses.

The photograph is likely taken from the perspective of another vehicle or a stationary point on the street, as evidenced by part of a tree trunk and its foliage framing the right side of the image. This all combines to provide a lively snapshot of city life, showcasing the transportation and architecture of the time.
title: Metropolitan Atlanta rapid transit authority (marta) buses in downtown Atlanta, Georgia.  Voters have authorized a one percent sales tax for improving the transit system.  In 1974 it brought in $53 million.  A $1.79 billion 53-mile rapid rail transit system was scheduled to begin construction in may, 1975, but was held up by legal battles.  In 1974 marta carried 73,727,000 passengers, an increase of 27 percent from 1970 to 1974
